pageContext.desc: To Chicago lawyer and Congressman John V. LeMoyne, from his Pennsylvania-based family, including his abolitionist father.
transcription:
Recd aug 4/63
Mentions the clock
John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

July 30th

My darling Johnny
how truly glad I was to receive your
little note today for verily you have
scarcely been out of my mind since I 
left you. I think over all my visit
think of the very dear sweet good
children and wish I could see them
often. cherish them and teach them
all that is good and generous and 
true - and for that you must go
to the fountain head, go to the work
of God. what can be better than the
instructions of our Creator. moreover
he has promised with his instruction
his "unclear" his powerful and
enlightening spirit - And with what
earnest anguish does my heart 
go out to God for his blessing on 
you & yours - As to our life's afflictions
are they not but as the - of the
balance compared to the joys of 
eternal life - May we live as to
meet our God & Saviour with joy -

I suppose when I wrote to Jane you read my letters. But n'importe they were not worth much. I never feel much like writing at first - but I suppose she told you of my reception. I did not know whether I ought to tell, but concluded you would want to know. But you must not any of you entertain impolite or improper feelings about these things I have ceased to suffer any more than the sorrow that sin is committed and that I am the occasion of it - it would be a great deal easier for me to bear all this if it did not cause my children to do or feel wrong - that is my trial. So keep quiet and feel good and all will yet be well. Jane suggests half or quite in jest that Mr Harding join your [h?] and bring Nanny. She has been so sick for ten days and is so nervous - that she really
